Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Novel compact cell settlers for high cell density perfusion cultures of mammalian cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is the development of a novel compact cell settler that can selectively remove dead cells and cell debris from the cell culture broth and completely recycle all the live and productive cells back to the continuous perfusion bioreactor. As this membrane-free device is not prone to clogging like the competing membrane-based cell retention devices, a single perfusion bioreactor culture does not need to be terminated prematurely after 3 or 4 weeks (due to accumulation of dead cells and cell debris resulting in reduced product quality and clogged membranes in current devices). The novel compact cell settler has a small size and footprint compared with other cell retention devices, and increases the likelihood of wider adaptation of the technology by a larger number of biomanufacturing companies and reduces the cost of manufacture of therapeutic biologics. As biosimilar price competition is expected for successful products that are coming off patent protection, reducing the cost of their manufacture using superior cell culture techniques will enable increased affordability of these drugs to a wider patient population.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to develop a novel compact and more efficient method of scaling up inclined settler technology, which has been scaled up inefficiently as rectilinear lamellar settlers. While a few biological manufacturers have successfully adapted the protruding lamellar settlers to manufacture therapeutic biologics from recombinant mammalian cells in high cell density perfusion bioreactors, the proposed novel compact cell settler is predicted to achieve the required separation of dead cells and cell debris from a high cell density perfusion bioreactor with a much smaller footprint compared to the original inclined lamellar settler design. Three key objectives for the research are to 1) demonstrate that the novel compact cell settler can achieve and maintain high viable cell densities indefinitely, 2) determine the maximum perfusion rate that maintain the high viable cell density indefinitely for smaller settlers of two different sizes, and 3) develop new scaling laws that can predict the size requirements of the settlers for larger commercial-scale bioreactors. These objectives will be accomplished by a systematic experimental plan to investigate the performance of the novel settlers at two different sizes and for two different mammalian cell types.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This SBIR Phase I project demonstrated the capability of our novel compact cell settler with conical and cylindrical geometries for removing selectively the smaller dead mammalian cells and cell debris from the bioreactor, recycling the larger live and productive cells back to bioreactor, and achieving high cell densities and viabilities in a continuous perfusion bioreactor.  After overcoming several small technical hurdles initially, we have successfully demonstrated that our settlers can indeed remove dead cells and cell debris selectively from the top port of the settler, recycle live and productive cells from the bottom port back to the bioreactor and achieve high cell densities (~20 million cells/ml) and viabilities (~90%) inside the perfusion bioreactor operated for over two weeks.

 

Figure 1.  Size distribution histograms for the samples from the bioreactor (blue) and the settler’s top effluent (red) showing very clearly that the smaller dead cells and cell debris (size range less than 12 microns) are removed preferentially in the top effluent of our compact cell settler. More importantly, very few of the live and productive CHO cells (size range 12 – 30 microns) are removed in the settler top effluent.

 

Figure 2. Size distributions of cells in samples from the bioreactor (blue), settler top effluent (red) and settler bottom return (green) demonstrate our central hypothesis that our compact cell settler can selectively remove the smaller dead cells and cell debris in the effluent, while returning the live and productive cells completely to the perfusion bioreactor.

 

Figure 3 shows the attachment of our novel 6” compact cell settler to a perfusion bioreactor.  

 

Figure 4. High cell densities and increasing viabilities of CHO cells achieved in a 1.5 liter continuous perfusion bioreactor attached with our compact cell settler integrated with an electric shaker, at increasing perfusion or harvest rates over a 2 week culture duration.

 

Figure 5 shows several settlers made in different sizes (4”, 6” & 12” diameter) used in our experiments

 

Peer-reviewed Publication & Conference Presentations from the SBIR Phase 1 Findings:

 

Freeman, C.A., P.S.D. Samuel, and D.S. Kompala, “Compact cell settlers for perfusion cultures of microbial (and mammalian) cells”, Biotechnology Progress 33:913-922 (2017). DOI 10.1002/btpr.2533

 

Kompala, D.S. “Compact cell settlers” short 2 minute oral presentation at NIIMBL inaugural meeting at the National Academy of Sciences (May 2017) & 1 minute oral presentations at NIIMBL teaming events at Genentech,  N.C. State University (July 2017) and Celgene (Sept 2017).

 

Kompala, D.S. “Novel compact cell settler for high cell density perfusion bioreactor cultures of microbial (and mammalian) cells,” Invited 20 minute oral presentation in the combined session on “Continuous Manufacturing” and “Microbial Manufacturing” at BioProduction Congress, Dublin, Ireland, October 17, 2017.

 

Published Patent Applications:

 1. U.S. Patent Application Serial No. 15/586,902, filed May 4, 2017 (Title: “PARTICLE SETTLING DEVICES”), published as US2017/0333815 A1 on Nov 23, 2017.

 2. PCT Patent Application Serial No. PCT/US17/31252, filed May 5, 2017 (Title: “PARTICLE SETTLING DEVICES”) published as WO2017192966A1 on Nov 9, 2017.

After overcoming several small technical hurdles initially, we have successfully demonstrated that our settlers can indeed remove dead cells and cell debris selectively from the top port of the settler, recycle live and productive cells from the bottom port back to the bioreactor and achieve high cell densities (~20 million cells/ml) and viabilities (~90%) inside the perfusion bioreactor operated for over two weeks.
